articles.headline: Hillary Clinton’s Long Road to ‘Sorry’ Over Email Use
articles.snippet: After a tumultuous lifetime in politics, Mrs. Clinton’s instincts have repeatedly guided her toward digging in, not giving in, when under attack.
articles.abstract: After a tumultuous lifetime in politics, Mrs. Clinton’s instincts have repeatedly guided her toward digging in, not giving in, when under attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton did not want to apologize.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Amy Chozick

articles.headline: High-Tech Lights to Help Baby Sleep, or Students Stay Alert
articles.snippet: New types of specialty bulbs are being used or tested in health applications, to enhance learning or alertness, create a mood, or aid in sleep.
articles.abstract: New types of specialty bulbs are being used or tested in health applications, to enhance learning or alertness, create a mood, or aid in sleep.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like many expecting parents, Tracy Mizraki Kraft in Portola Valley, Calif., worried about how her newborn would sleep. So she paid attention when her doctor handed her a light bulb that he said would help her son do just that.

articles.headline: U.S. Drops Charges That Professor Shared Technology With China
articles.snippet: All charges against the Temple University professor were dropped after it became apparent the Justice Department had misinterpreted a key piece of evidence.
articles.abstract: All charges against the Temple University professor were dropped after it became apparent the Justice Department had misinterpreted a key piece of evidence.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Justice Department arrested the chairman of Temple University’s physics department this spring and accused him of sharing sensitive American-made technology with China, prosecutors had what seemed like a damning piece of evidence: schematics of sophisticated laboratory equipment sent by the professor, Xi Xiaoxing, to scientists in China.

articles.headline: California Legislature Approves Assisted Suicide
articles.snippet: If Gov. Jerry Brown signs the measure, the state will become the fifth to allow doctors to prescribe life-ending medication to some patients.
articles.abstract: If Gov. Jerry Brown signs the measure, the state will become the fifth to allow doctors to prescribe life-ending medication to some patients.
articles.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — In a landmark victory for supporters of assisted suicide, the California State Legislature on Friday gave its final approval to a bill that would allow doctors to help terminally ill people end their lives.

articles.headline: Banks to Settle With Investors in Suit Over Financial Crisis
articles.snippet: Large investors had sued 12 of the world’s largest banks for conspiring to unfairly control a derivatives market at the center of the financial crisis.
articles.abstract: Large investors had sued 12 of the world’s largest banks for conspiring to unfairly control a derivatives market at the center of the financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Large banks are preparing to pay $1.865 billion to settle accusations that they conspired unfairly to control a derivatives market that stood at the center of the financial crisis, a lawyer suing the banks said in court on Friday.

articles.headline: Automakers Will Make Automatic Braking Systems Standard in New Cars
articles.snippet: The automakers have not set a timetable for the introduction of the systems, and regulators may still seek government rules that would require the equipment as a standard feature in all cars and trucks.
articles.abstract: The automakers have not set a timetable for the introduction of the systems, and regulators may still seek government rules that would require the equipment as a standard feature in all cars and trucks.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Federal regulators said on Friday that 10 automakers had agreed to install automatic braking systems, which use sensors to detect potential collisions, as standard equipment in new vehicles.

articles.headline: Google, Twitter and Publishers Seek Faster Web
articles.snippet: The goal is to develop a universal standard for publishers — one that could be used to load articles more quickly wherever they appear.
articles.abstract: The goal is to develop a universal standard for publishers — one that could be used to load articles more quickly wherever they appear.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In a world where many people read everything on mobile phones, a few seconds of load time can mean the gain or loss of millions of readers and advertising dollars.
articles.byline: By Conor Dougherty and Vindu Goel

articles.headline: The Fed’s Policy Mechanics Retool for a Rise in Interest Rates
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve threw so much money at the financial crisis and recovery that it must take yet another unconventional approach to begin unwinding the stimulus.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve threw so much money at the financial crisis and recovery that it must take yet another unconventional approach to begin unwinding the stimulus.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s easy to take for granted the Federal Reserve’s ability to raise interest rates. Even among the legions who doubt that Fed officials will pick the ideal moment to start increasing rates for the first time since 2008, few question the Fed’s technical competence. The central bank has a long history. The engine is known to work.

articles.headline: Eastern Bloc’s Resistance to Refugees Highlights Europe’s Cultural and Political Divisions
articles.snippet: Eastern Europe's resistance to taking in migrants is the latest evidence of the stubborn cultural and political divides that persist between East and West.
articles.abstract: Eastern Europe's resistance to taking in migrants is the latest evidence of the stubborn cultural and political divides that persist between East and West.
articles.lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Even though the former Communist countries of Central and Eastern Europe have been asked to accept just a tiny fraction of the refugees that Germany and other nations are taking, their fierce resistance now stands as the main impediment to a unified European response to the crisis.

articles.headline: A Dying Young Woman’s Hope in Cryonics and a Future
articles.snippet: Cancer claimed Kim Suozzi at age 23, but she chose to have her brain preserved with the dream that neuroscience might one day revive her mind.
articles.abstract: Cancer claimed Kim Suozzi at age 23, but she chose to have her brain preserved with the dream that neuroscience might one day revive her mind.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the moments just before Kim Suozzi died of cancer at age 23, it fell to her boyfriend, Josh Schisler, to follow through with the plan to freeze her brain.

articles.headline: Gloomy Republican Campaigns Leave Behind Reagan Cheer
articles.snippet: Damning assessments of the country’s condition have become an especially powerful part of the message sounded by several Republicans seeking their party’s nomination for the presidency.
articles.abstract: Damning assessments of the country’s condition have become an especially powerful part of the message sounded by several Republicans seeking their party’s nomination for the presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: To listen to the way some Republicans tell it, America is a pretty awful place these days.

articles.headline: Airstrikes Take Toll on Civilians in Yemen War
articles.snippet: A Saudi-led aerial campaign against the Houthis, a rebel militia movement, has become so broad and vicious that critics accuse the coalition of collectively punishing people living in areas the Houthis control.
articles.abstract: A Saudi-led aerial campaign against the Houthis, a rebel militia movement, has become so broad and vicious that critics accuse the coalition of collectively punishing people living in areas the Houthis control.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAJJA, Yemen — The airstrike slammed into Al-Sham water-bottling plant at the end of the night shift, killing 13 workers who were minutes away from heading home.

articles.headline: Germany Orders Curbs at Border in Migrant Crisis
articles.snippet: The move was seen as a strong sign that Germany was growing weary of shouldering so much of the burden for Europe’s largest humanitarian crisis in decades.
articles.abstract: The move was seen as a strong sign that Germany was growing weary of shouldering so much of the burden for Europe’s largest humanitarian crisis in decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — With record numbers of migrants pouring across the Hungarian border and rushing west, Germany, the country that had been the most welcoming in Europe, suddenly ordered temporary border restrictions on Sunday that cut off rail travel from Austria and instituted spot checks on cars.
articles.byline: By Melissa Eddy, Rick Lyman and Alison Smale

articles.headline: Jeb Bush’s Cerebral Debate Style Faces a Test: Donald Trump
articles.snippet: In rigorous practice sessions for Wednesday’s Republican debate, Mr. Bush has been preparing pointed responses to Mr. Trump’s most frequent insults.
articles.abstract: In rigorous practice sessions for Wednesday’s Republican debate, Mr. Bush has been preparing pointed responses to Mr. Trump’s most frequent insults.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the debate stage, Jeb Bush has committed the sin of over-explanation, answering a pithy 1994 attack on his business career with so many details about leases and debts that a baffled crowd erupted into boos.

articles.headline: Rivalry Builds Off the Field as Talent Agencies Turn to Sports
articles.snippet: With the movie and television businesses facing an uncertain future, Creative Artists Agency and William Morris Endeavor are going all in on athletics.
articles.abstract: With the movie and television businesses facing an uncertain future, Creative Artists Agency and William Morris Endeavor are going all in on athletics.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As the National Football League begins another season, almost a third of its starting quarterbacks — including Peyton Manning and Drew Brees — will be represented by Creative Artists Agency. And as Novak Djokovic won the U.S. Open on Sunday, his team from William Morris Endeavor was in the stands cheering him on.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Etsy Welcomes Manufacturers to Artisanal Fold
articles.snippet: With Etsy Manufacturing, the online marketplace plans to connect sellers and small manufacturers that meet certain production and workplace criteria.
articles.abstract: With Etsy Manufacturing, the online marketplace plans to connect sellers and small manufacturers that meet certain production and workplace criteria.
articles.lead_paragraph: Molly Goodall’s store on Etsy, the online crafts marketplace, started as a creative solution to a parenting problem.

articles.headline: U.S. and Iran Both Conflict and Converge
articles.snippet: With the nuclear deal having cleared its biggest congressional hurdle, the United States will have to navigate an increasingly complicated regional maze with a newly empowered Iran.
articles.abstract: With the nuclear deal having cleared its biggest congressional hurdle, the United States will have to navigate an increasingly complicated regional maze with a newly empowered Iran.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — American troops advising Iraqi security forces in restive Anbar Province are sharing a base with odd bedfellows: an Iranian-backed militia that once killed United States soldiers. Both are fighting the militants of the Islamic State.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Baidu and CloudFlare Boost Users Over China’s Great Firewall
articles.snippet: The Chinese search giant Baidu and CloudFlare, a start-up based in San Francisco, have joined in an unusual business arrangement to speed Internet traffic into and out of China.
articles.abstract: The Chinese search giant Baidu and CloudFlare, a start-up based in San Francisco, have joined in an unusual business arrangement to speed Internet traffic into and out of China.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — It is one of the best-guarded borders in the world, and one of the most time-consuming to cross. Yet in the past few months, a new agreement has let people speed over it billions of times.

articles.headline: One Symptom in New Medical Codes: Doctor Anxiety
articles.snippet: Under the new coding regime, government programs and private insurers will require doctors, hospitals, clinics and nursing homes to report vastly more information about the care they provide patients.
articles.abstract: Under the new coding regime, government programs and private insurers will require doctors, hospitals, clinics and nursing homes to report vastly more information about the care they provide patients.
articles.lead_paragraph: TERRE HAUTE, Ind. — The nation’s health care providers are under orders to start using a new system of medical codes to describe illnesses and injuries in more detail than ever before. The codes will cover common ailments: Did a diabetic also have kidney disease? But also included are some that are far less common: whether the patient was crushed by a crocodile or sucked into a jet engine.

articles.headline: Pitfalls for the Unwary Borrower Out on the Frontiers of Banking
articles.snippet: Marketed as a way to get out of debt, loans from online lenders are instead leaving some people deeper underwater.
articles.abstract: Marketed as a way to get out of debt, loans from online lenders are instead leaving some people deeper underwater.
articles.lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley has helped enhance just about every aspect of modern life. Naturally, Mohammad Mansour figured it could help solve his money problems, too.

articles.headline: Intelligence Start-Up Goes Behind Enemy Lines to Get Ahead of Hackers
articles.snippet: ISight Partners has assembled a team of expert analysts fluent in 24 languages to infiltrate the underground and prevent criminals from attacking its clients.
articles.abstract: ISight Partners has assembled a team of expert analysts fluent in 24 languages to infiltrate the underground and prevent criminals from attacking its clients.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHANTILLY, Va. — On a recent Wednesday morning, 100 intelligence analysts crammed into a nondescript conference room here and dialed into a group call with 100 counterparts in Argentina, Brazil, Cyprus, India, the Netherlands, Romania, Spain, Taiwan and Ukraine.

articles.headline: Which Fed Leaders Fear Inflation? Look at When They Grew Up
articles.snippet: Economic events during formative years might exert an outsize influence on how policy makers see the world. That’s an argument for studying history.
articles.abstract: Economic events during formative years might exert an outsize influence on how policy makers see the world. That’s an argument for studying history.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you are an 18-year-old college freshman in the United States, inflation in your lifetime has averaged less than 2 percent. If you are a 30-year-old millennial, you experienced inflation above 5 percent for only one year — when you were in kindergarten, perhaps in the form of the coins in a piggy bank buying fewer pieces of candy the longer they sat unspent.

articles.headline: More Border Controls as Europe Stalls on Migrant Quotas
articles.snippet: The interior ministers agreed to share 40,000 migrants sheltering in Greece and Italy, but only on a voluntary basis, a watered-down version of a plan announced in May.
articles.abstract: The interior ministers agreed to share 40,000 migrants sheltering in Greece and Italy, but only on a voluntary basis, a watered-down version of a plan announced in May.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Even as three more countries followed Germany in introducing border checks to control a flood of migrants, the European Union on Monday failed to agree on a modest plan that would force individual countries to take in a share of some of the hundreds of thousands now seeking asylum in Europe.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins and James Kanter

articles.headline: Russian Moves in Syria Widen Role in Mideast
articles.snippet: American officials said the movement of modern battle tanks into Syria was part of an escalating buildup that could give Moscow its most significant military foothold in the Middle East in decades.
articles.abstract: American officials said the movement of modern battle tanks into Syria was part of an escalating buildup that could give Moscow its most significant military foothold in the Middle East in decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russia has sent some of its most modern battle tanks to a new air base in Syria in what American officials said Monday was part of an escalating buildup that could give Moscow its most significant military foothold in the Middle East in decades.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: A Departure for Ai Weiwei at the Royal Academy in London
articles.snippet: A large exhibition highlights his Chinese work but ushers in a new phase.
articles.abstract: A large exhibition highlights his Chinese work but ushers in a new phase.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The opening of Britain’s largest-ever survey of Ai WeiWei at the Royal Academy of Arts this week has featured an important — and, until recently, unexpected — guest: the Chinese artist-activist himself.

articles.headline: The Lobbyist With a Six-Figure Government Job
articles.snippet: As executive director of a federal agency, Jeffrey Farrow makes over $100,000 a year. At the same time, he has lobbied for clients overseas.
articles.abstract: As executive director of a federal agency, Jeffrey Farrow makes over $100,000 a year. At the same time, he has lobbied for clients overseas.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In this city with a grand tradition of government officials who pass through the revolving door into a world of big paychecks, Jeffrey Farrow stands apart.
